subject: UBS Weekly FX Flows Report: Significant safe-haven inflows as CAD swings to most sold
content:
- CHF saw the largest normalized inflows in G10, likely driven by weak global risk sentiment in a relatively light data week for Switzerland
- JPY was materially bought vs USD and EUR despite a weaker-than expected Eco Watchers Survey and news that BoJ Gov Kuroda is likely to be re-appointed to another term
- CHF and JPY saw majority of inflows early in the week, coinciding with the equity market sell-off
- SEK, NOK, and NZD were also bid, suggesting that FX market risk aversion was not quite as broad-based as other markets
- CAD was the most sold G10 ahead of labour data uncertainty on Friday
- EUR experienced heavy selling pressure in the last 4 days of the week
- GBP was net sold for a fourth straight week, with heavy outflows vs USD following the BoE meeting

content:
ASIA-PAC

Chinese New Yuan Loans (CNY)(Jan) 2900B vs. Exp. 2000.0B (Prev. 584.4B). (Newswires)
Chinese Aggregate Financing (CNY)(Jan) 3060.0B vs. Exp. 3150.0B (Prev. 1139.8B)
Chinese M2 Money Supply YY (Jan) 8.6% vs. Exp. 8.4% (Prev. 8.2%)

Indian CPI (YY) (Jan) 5.07% vs. Exp. 5.14% (Prev. 5.21%)

Japan may tighten cap on forex trading by individuals. (Nikkei)

RBA Assistant Governor Ellis said wage growth will pick up gradually not immediately, and that retail competition is to work against wage pressures. (Newswires)

New Zealand 6-month budget surplus was NZD 779mln larger than expected and core revenues were almost NZD 600mln higher than forecast, according to the government’s 6-month financial statements. (Newswires)


NORTH AMERICA

US President Trump said the US will reveal a reciprocal tax with other countries later on in the week. (Newswires)

 

US BUDGET: The White House sent Congress a request for a $4.4trln budget, which seemingly does away with the Republican principle of aiming to achieve a balanced budget within a 10-year horizon. The budget called for $1.7trln cuts in mandatory spending over 10-years, $200bln in infrastructure investment, as well as a budget for the Wall. The economic assumptions in the budget also received attention, which is more optimistic on growth in the short-term (than the FOMC’s recent forecasts, as well as analyst consensus), is slightly lower than consensus, unemployment in line with the market and the FOMC. However, the assumptions assume a 10-year yield of 2.60% this year – benchmark 10s are currently yielding around 25bps more than the assumption. Congress will need to vote on the budget before it is adopted.

 

EQUITIES: SPX +1.4% at 2656, DJI +1.7% at 24600, NDX +1.7% at 6524.
Top sectors: Materials +2.1%, IT +1.7%, Energy +1.6%.
Bottom sectors: Telecoms +0.5%Utilities +0.7%, Healthcare +0.9%.

After last week’s slide, major stock indices continued the ‘recovery’, posting a second day of gains, in a further sign that last week’s selloff was technical/sentiment/position adjustment-related. Gains were broad-based, led by Apple and Boeing, while Cisco and American Express were higher on broker upgrades. Sector wise, materials and industrials were higher after Trump announced the much-awaited infrastructure plan, which will see the Federal government invest $200bln (which it is hoped will be boosted to $1.5trln after public-private partnerships), and the defence spending boost. Energy was tracking the crude complex higher, while financials benefited from higher yields. The analyst community continued to talk up the buy-the-dip potential of the market, after bears failed to force a close beneath the 200d MA on Friday. The VIX, meanwhile, slipped to the 25-handle, having surged above 40 last week. (RANsquawk)

TREASURIES: US T-Notes settle 9 ticks lower at 120-25+.

Yields were slightly higher across the curve on Monday, with most of the action concentrated in the belly of the curve. The Tplex took its cue from continued ‘recovery’ in risk sentiment after last week, with 10s moving back to test 2.9% unsuccessfully, settling around 2.85%. Analysts were also citing concerns about the level of US deficits, and are mindful of inflation data, due Wednesday, for signs whether inflationary pressures are widespread, or fleeting/contained in certain areas. The US Treasury will also auction a new 30-year TIPS for $7bln, ahead of next week’s new 2s, 5s and 7s. (RANsquawk)


UK

Irish PM Varadkar said the country would like a comprehensive free trade agreement with the UK following Brexit and notes talks are moving in the right direction. (Newswires)

BoE’s Vlieghe stated if there is less credit headwinds, it may signal the UK is ready for higher rates and that there is increased evidence that a tight labour market is having an upward effect on wages. Later on he stated the central bank is doing macro prudential tightening but it is also appropriate to raise rates. Vlieghe stressed that there is huge uncertainty over the rate path and said rates could go up faster or more slowly.

BoE’s McCafferty said the UK economy is holding up relatively well and it is likely rates will have to rise earlier than we thought late last year and noted it is too early to say whether the BoE will hike in May. (Newswires)


FX

DXY down 0.25% heading into APAC trade Some analysts have noted that DXY trades like a funding currency these days, inversing moving with market sentiment. Most of those losses for the DXY came as a result of EUR rising 0.4%, though the range was thin (1.2236 to 12296), as was newsflow; comments from ECB’s Nowotny made over the weekend continued to get traction (another warning about US political influence in the USD, which he suggested may be discussed at the March G20 meeting). Even the havens traded higher against the Buck; the yen was strengthening on reports that BOJ governor Kuroda was set to be reappointed. XAU was up by $7 to reclaim the $1320 level. Sterling was more-or-less flat against the USD, and around 0.25% weaker against the EUR; BOE’s Haldane suggested over the weekend that the BOE was in no rush to hike rates, while BOE’s Vlighe noted uncertainty about the rate path and rates could go up faster or more slowly, and BOE’s McCafferty said it was too early to say if the Bank would hike in May. Attention will be on the “Road to Brexit” speeches over the next three weeks, where senior UK officials (including PM May and Foreign Minister Johnson) will detail what the UK wants The ZAR was outperforming its EMFX copunterparts, trading around 1% higher against the dollar on anticipation that the ANC’s NEC meeting would finally come to a resolve to oust President Zuma. There was mixed newsflow – at one point, local press reported that Zuma was on the cusp of resigning, which was subsequently denied by Presidential sources. Nevertheless, ZAR maintained most of the gains. (RANsquawk)

South African President Zuma is reported to want a 3-month ‘notice period’ before resigning, although South Africa media cited sources in which it stated that President Zuma has been given 48 hours to resign. (Business Day/Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

CRUDE: WTI futures settled 9 cents higher at $59.29 per barrel; Brent futures settled 20 cents lower at $62.59 per barrel. Once again, crude was tracking overall risk sentiment for most of the session – specifically taking its cue from stock markets and the US dollar. Crude bulls were happy to ignore Friday’s Baker Hughes rig count data, which showed oil drillers adding oil rigs for the third straight week; bulls also looked-through the OPEC monthly oil market report – where 2018 supply was raised by 250k BPD to 1.4m BPD, demand growth bumped up by 60k to 1.59m BPD, and the implied call on OPEC’s crude trimmed by 240k BPD to 32.86m BPD. However, heading into settlement, the EIA reported that US shale regions production in March was expected to rise by 111k BPD taking it to 6.757mln BPD (Feb. saw a 109k BPD increase). In pre-settlement trade, both WTI and Brent gave back the bulk of gains. (RANsquawk)

OPEC MONTHLY REPORT: OPEC crude production -8k bpd in January to average 32.30mln bpd, according to secondary sources; 137% compliance
- Crude oil output increased in Iraq, Saudi Arabia and Libya although this was mainly offset by decreasing production in Venezuela and Angola
- 2018 oil demand growth was revised up 60k bpd to 1.59mln bpd, leading to total global consumption of 98.6mln bpd.
- 2018 non-OPEC supply growth revised up by 320k bpd to 1.40mln bpd, driven by higher production from US, Mexico, Brazil and China.
- World oil supply in January increased 350k bpd to average 97.67mln bpd, an increase of 1.75mln bpd Y/Y.
- OPEC crude for 2018 revised down by 0.2mln bpd to 32.9mln bpd.

According to EIA, US Total Shale Regions Oil Production in March forecasts an increase of 111k BPD at 6.757mln BPD (Feb. saw a 109k BPD increase). (Newswires)

UAE energy minister stated the energy market is to balance this year; additionally stated that shale oil output is to be absorbed by rising 2018 demand. (Newswires)

Russia's Novak says it could take two to five months to exit global oil output deal. (Newswires)

North Sea Forties pipeline is now said to be in full operation; according to sources. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US not backing down from North Korean confrontation, according to official’s being cited by Free Beacon. (Free Beacon)

subject: FX Daily Wrap: Mundane Monday with minimal movement in majors
content: The Dollar attempted to reclaim and reverse losses vs some G10 rivals ahead of the Wall Street open, as the Index inched up over 90.4000, but key or psychological levels vs the Eur, Gbp and Cad for example basically held in (55 DMA at 1.2239, 1.3800 and daily pivot resistance at 1.2610 respectively). Usd/Jpy and Usd/Chf remained relatively rangebound between 108.50-95 and 0.9400-0.9365 despite broadly risk back on sentiment, which helped the Aud more than its Nzd peer as the cross recovered the 1.0800 handle (former rebounding towards 0.7850 vs the Usd, latter stalling around the middle of its 0.7230-75 band). Much more excitement and action in the EM area where Usd/Zar initially dropped to around 11.8825 on reports that Zuma had finally agreed to step down, but the Rand essentially reversing course when a Presidential spokesman refuted the resignation talk. Back to the Greenback, attention on early details of the Trump infrastructure plan before the focus shifts to January’s Federal Budget.

Update on President Zuma (Zexit)
content:
So while the ANC looks set to recall President Zuma today, the decision itself is not enough to unseat President from office.

Zuma has one or two options, resign from office like his predecessor, which would avoid a tricky parliamentary process where the opposition parties could gain political points and as such be in the ANC’s best interest. The second option would be for Zuma to refuse to resign and would then face a vote of no confidence which is currently scheduled for February 22nd, whereby a small majority is needed to oust the President and other members of the cabinet.

United Tech (UTX) – Airbus warned about new issues with United Tech’s Pratt & Whitney engine. (Newswires)

 

S&P500

Andeavor (ANDV) / Delek US (DK) – Delek has said it reached a definitive agreement to sell four asphalt terminals to an affiliate of Andeavor. (Newswires)

Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A) – An insurance subsidy of the co. is said to have established a unit in Dubai International Financial Centre, following the approval of a licence by regulators. The subsidiary will provide brokerage services focused on energy, construction, property, marine and it has appointed Alessandro Cerase as senior executive officer for the Dubai and other Asian units. (Newswires)

Citigroup (C) – The bank is still going to invest in London despite Brexit, it will set up an innovation centre and initially employ 60 technologists. (FT)

CME Group (CME) – High speed traders have reportedly been exploiting a glitch which creates a tiny gap between private trade confirmations and public data feed. (WSJ)

Equifax (EFX) – The tech. co.’s data breach is reportedly worse than originally exposed. (Newswires)

Ford (F) – The automaker is increasing its production of its Lincoln Navigator and Ford Expedition. (Newswires)

General Dynamics (GD) – The co. is to purchase CSRA for USD 9.6bln (USD 40.75/shr) and sees the deal as accretive to earnings and FCF next year. (Newswires)

Infrastructure Names (JEC, ACM, VMC, USCR, CAT) / Steel Names (X, AKS) – US President Trump should release the infrastructure plan today which will show how much is going to be spent on infrastructure, the expected value is USD 200bln. (Newswires)

Macy’s (M) – American International Group reported a 7.9% stake in the retailer. (Newswires)

Monsanto (MON) - Margrethe Verstager, from the European Union Competition Commission, reported to a German newspaper over the weekend that Bayer (BAYN GY) is to ensure the merger with the Monsanto does not harm competition in digital farming. (Newswires)

Newell (NWL) – Starboard Value raised concerns about significant underperformance in the co. Further, Starboard and Opportunity Master Fund want to nominate 10 directors to its board, including 3 former operators of Jarden Corp. (Newswires)

Oracle (ORCL) – The co. announced it is planning to increase its modern cloud infrastructure footprint. (Newswires)

Ryder (R) – The co. declared a quarterly dividend of USD 0.45/shr. (Newswires)

Tyson Foods (TSN) – The co. is experiencing troubles with selling some of its non-chicken business. (NY Post)

UPS (UPS) – The delivery co. increased its board size to 13 members following a recommendation from its Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee, Christiana Shi has been elected to the board. (Newswires)

Wells Fargo (WFC) – The bank is struggling to refund its customers who were forced to purchase insurance which was not needed. (WSJ)

 

NASDAQ 100

Alphabet (GOOG) – The tech giant’s Waymo is facing larger challenges following the settlement with Uber. (NY Times)

Amazon (AMZN), Intel (INTC), AMD (AMD) - Amazon's USD 90mln deal to acquire Blink home security cameras last year is reportedly a secret bet on the Blink's energy-efficient chips, according to sources. (Newswires)

Amgen (AMGN) – The biotech co. is reportedly searching for acquisitions using a USD 27bln cash pile but is experiencing troubles finding targets. (FT)

Baidu (BIDU) – The tech co. and iClick Interactive Asia have strengthened the partnership between the two. (Newswires)

Fox (FOXA) / Comcast (CMCSA) – Comcast is considering making a new offer for Fox. According to people familiar with the matter, the previous bid at USD 60bln was rejected due to potential regulatory concerns. Separately, Fox said it would commit to maintain Sky News in Britain for at least 5 years which would establish a board for the channel to try to secure its takeover of Pay-Tv Sky operator. (Newswires)

Qualcomm (QCOM) / Broadcom (AVGO) – The two tech companies are to meet on February 14th, and Broadcom have secured USD 100bln in debt financing for the acquisition. (Newswires)

Wynn Resorts (WYNN) – The co. has said Steve Wynn has no immediate plans to sell its shares. Further, the co. board stops its outside investigation of former CEO, Steve Wynn. (Newswires / WSJ)

Celanese (CE) – The co. raises its price of its Acetaldehyde in Europe. (Newswires)

Snap (SNAP) – The social media co. attempted to purchase a defunct messaging app called Secret for up to USD 60mln, however in 2014 it was valued at USD 120mln in a series B round in 2014. (Newswires)

Teva (TEVA) – The pharmaceutical co. announced the launch of QVAR RediHaler in US. (Newswires)

subject: PRIMER: US FY 2019 Budget – details to be announced on Monday (no time set)
content:
US President Trump will make his 2019 budget request to Congress on Monday. Attention will be on details around infrastructure spending, as well as the trajectory of the US budget deficit. There is no set time for the release of the budget details.

DEFICITS:

- It has been widely suggested that the Republican budget will abandon a long-established principle to maintain a balanced budget over a 10-year horizon (WaPo) – a notion given credence after last week’s bipartisan spending plan. The US Congressional Budget Office estimated that the spending plan would add more than USD 1 trillion to federal budget deficits over 10-years, even after they factor in the assumed economic growth that would be stimulated.

- However, OMB Director Mulvaney over the weekend intimated that the 2019 budget would propose a USD 3trln cut to deficits over 10-years, but provided few details. Mulvaney also suggested that all of the funding requested in the budget would not necessarily have to be spent.

- Traders will, therefore, keep an eye out for details, as well as independent scoring of the budget that will follow in the days ahead. Some have suggested that part of the fixed-income sell-off last week was attributed to the anticipated widening deficits, as well as increased supply out of the US Treasury.

INFRASTRUCTURE:

- As has been widely suggested since Trump’s State of The Union address, the US govt is expected to inject USD 200bln in spending in order to spur a total of USD 1.5trln in investments from state, local and private partners (Reuters).

- Analysts have suggested keeping an eye on the following equity names: Martin Marietta Materials (MLM), Aecom (ACM), Jacobs Engineering Group (JEC), Granite Construction (GVA), Eagle Materials (EXP), U.S. Concrete (USCR), Caterpillar (CAT).

- In more politically-focussed factors, reports suggest that the budget will request USD 23bln for enhanced border security (read: the wall), helping Trump to fulfil a key campaign pledge.

OPEC MONTHLY REPORT: OPEC crude production -8k bpd in January to average 32.30mln bpd, according to secondary sources; 137% compliance
content:
- Crude oil output increased in Iraq, Saudi Arabia and Libya although this was mainly offset by decreasing production in Venezuela and Angola

- 2018 oil demand growth was revised up 60k bpd to 1.59mln bpd, leading to total global consumption of 98.6mln bpd.

- 2018 non-OPEC supply growth revised up by 320k bpd to 1.40mln bpd, driven by higher production from US, Mexico, Brazil and China.

- World oil supply in January increased 350k bpd to average 97.67mln bpd, an increase of 1.75mln bpd Y/Y.

- OPEC crude for 2018 revised down by 0.2mln bpd to 32.9mln bpd

subject: Telia (TELIA SS) has held talks with TDC (TDC DC) board on possible bid for the Danish company
DAILY US OPENING NEWS: European bourses catch up to the gains seen late Friday on Wall Street
content:
12th February 2018

  • European bourses catch up to the gains seen late Friday on Wall Street
  • A relatively quiet start to the week in FX, partly due to Japan’s market holiday, but also as many participants simply take some time out after the hectic sessions of late
  • Looking ahead, today sees a lack of tier 1 highlights
     

ASIA

Asia equity markets began a holiday-quietened week mostly positive in which the region got a mild lift as US equity futures extended on Friday’s late rebound. However, upside was contained with Japan away in observance of National Founding Day, while the ASX 200 (-0.3%) was the laggard as energy names reeled from last week’s drop in crude prices and with financials subdued as the Royal Banking Commission started its inquiry into the industry. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) were positive ahead of this week’s Lunar New Year celebrations, while most of the Asia peripheries traded with cautious gains amid a lack of drivers and with various holiday closures scheduled through to next week.

PBoC skipped open market operations. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3001 (Prev. 6.3194).

 

CENTRAL BANK

BoE’s Haldane said that minor interest rate increases are likely to be introduced later this year, while he also stated that inflation is currently running above target and that’s one of the factors interest rates were hiked last year. (ChronicleLive)

BoE Vlieghe states that if there are less credit headwinds, this may signal that the UK is ready for higher rates, there is increased evidence that a tight labour market is having upward effects on wages, also stating that rise in UK debt burden not sustainable if continues for many years. (Newswires)

ECB’s Nowotny said that the ECB is concerned regarding US attempts to politically influence FX rates. Nowotny also added that said that EU inflation still has room to increase so the ECB is still on the careful side, although that certainly won’t last forever and that there will be a need for higher interest rates in the foreseeable future. (Newswires)

ECB’s Visco said ECB will be patient on pursuit of its inflation goal and that it has been challenging to push up inflation expectations. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

Office of Management and Budget Director Mulvaney said the is budget is to seek USD 3.0tln deficit reduction over 10 years and that interest rates may spike as a result of the increasing deficit, while he added that he would probably not have voted for the Trump budget deal. Furthermore, there were also source reports that Trump’s budget is said to not balance in 10 years. (Newswires)

US White House stated that 2019 budget plan will project 3% growth. (Newswires)

UK Chancellor Hammond has been sidelined from a series of major "road to Brexit" interventions by Cabinet ministers over the next fortnight as Theresa May seeks to agree a cross-Cabinet vision for Brexit. Theresa May and Boris Johnson, David Davis and Liam Fox - the three leading Cabinet Brexiteers - will all give key note speeches on the UK's EU withdrawal stance over the next three weeks, but the Chancellor will not take part. (Telegraph)

 

EQUITIES

European equities have kicked the week off on the front foot (Eurostoxx 50 +1.9%) as European bourses catch up with the gains seen late on Wall Street on Friday with macro newsflow otherwise light in the region. Sector wise, material names outperform in-fitting with some of the price action seen in the complex during Asia-Pac trade, energy names are also higher as energy prices continue to retrace some of the losses seen on Friday. In terms of stock specifics, Heineken (-4.2%) are seen lower after their earnings report was clouded by currency effects, Akzo Nobel (+1.7%) have been in focus today after reports in the FT suggesting the Co.’s chemicals unit has been subject to PE interest, Barclays (+1%) have been charged by the SFO regarding their Qatari loans and Airbus (-1.2%) are lower amid reports that they have stopped delivering A320neo jets due to issues with Pratt &Whitney engines.

FX

A relatively quiet start to the week, partly due to Japan’s market holiday, but also as many participants simply take some time out after the hectic sessions of late. The Usd is modestly weaker vs all its G10 peers bar the Kiwi, and then only just as Nzd/Usd nestles around 0.7250 and Aud/Nzd remains below 1.0800 – Aud/Usd maintaining 0.7800+ status. Cable has ticked up towards the top of a 1.3810-1.3875 range on little obvious Sterling supportive news or factors aside from further BoE rhetoric underscoring more policy tightening (albeit gradual), while Eur/Usd is mid-way between 1.2245-95 parameters amidst more qualms registered by ECB’s Nowotny about the US exerting political influence on exchange rates. Usd/Jpy even more contained within a 108.50-108.95 band, as are Usd/Chf and Usd/Cad in 0.9370-0.9400 and 1.2600-1.2555 ranges awaiting more direction – via stock market developments and US CPI data for example. The Dollar index is keeping its head above the 90.000 level with the latest weekly CFTC reports on spec positioning showing a slightly less short Greenback base, along with the Jpy, while Eur and Gbp longs lighten up a bit and Loonie longs increase their Cad holdings. In terms of option expiries, nothing really of note or in size for today’s NY cut.     

 

FIXED INCOME

Bunds have now technically breached that nearest downside technical objective at 157.56, but only just given the new/latest Eurex low at 157.54 (-1/2 point), and the lack of a clean break appears to have prompted some nibbling from jobbers perhaps looking for a bounce. Gilts continue to display relative resilience, but also extended the Liffe intraday low at 120.79 (-33 ticks) before finding a base, although may succumb to more selling pressure amidst comments from BoE’s Vlieghe underlining conditions that have changed to warrant higher rates. Meanwhile, USTs are hovering just above overnight session lows in futures and just under peaks on the cash yield front, awaiting the return of US traders for potentially the next legs down and higher respectively.

 

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korea invited South Korean President Moon for talks in Pyongyang, while President Moon stated that they should make preparations to realize the meeting. (Newswires)

US official stated that there is no differences between US, South Korea and Japan on need to isolate North Korea until it gives up its nuclear weapons program. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

In the commodities complex, both WTI and Brent crude futures have continued to retrace Friday’s losses despite Friday’s Baker Hughes rig count showing a climb of 26 oil rigs. In terms of energy newsflow, UAE energy minister stated the energy market is to balance this year with shale oil output to be absorbed by rising 2018 demand. In metals markets, spot gold is seen higher alongside the softer USD, although gains are likely being capped by this morning’s risk environment. Elsewhere, copper prices have recovered from their two month lows during London trade while Chinese iron ore futures were seen lower overnight after recent rampant gains ahead of the Lunar New Year which kicks off this Thursday.

North Sea Forties pipeline is now said to be in full operation, according to sources. (Newswires)

Phillips 66 reports a unit upset at wood river, Illinois refinery; the refinery has a crude capacity of 314K bpd. (Newswires)

UAE energy minister stated the energy market is to balance this year; additionally, stating that shale oil output is to be absorbed by rising 2018 demand. (Newswires)

subject: BoE Vlieghe wants to stress that there is huge uncertainty over rate path, could go up faster or more slowly
content: - he adds stronger world economy and labour market tightness is really telling us that further rise in rates is likely to be appropriate if strength continues

analysis_details: Forties pipeline has a capacity of 600k b/d and is a key UK crude transit route, exporting around 40% of the country's oil production, additionally, the route saw volumes average 445k b/d last year.

EU DEBT UPDATE: choppy trade pre/post-EU stock opens
content: Bunds bounced pretty well ahead of chart support around 157.56 to post a fresh 157.93 Eurex peak just before and on the EU cash equity opens, but faded in advance of the 158.00 handle as the Dax and counterparts essentially confirmed the positive starts to the week indicated by futures and external leads. Gilts actually climbed to 121.17 vs last Friday’s 121.12 close before conforming to the generally weaker core fixed tone and extending the downside to 120.86 from a 121.00 start and remain under par awaiting more independent impetus from BoE’s Vlieghe (9.30GMT) and/or McCafferty later (16.30GMT). Back to the German bond, nearest tech levels via a market contact are seen around 157.96-158.01, then 158.06 and 158.21 on the upside vs the aforementioned 157.56, 157.43 and last week’s 157.26 low.

Citi TOTW: Recommend buying EUR/AUD at 1.5667, with a target of 1.5925 and a stop at 1.5500
UK DEBT AND STIRS: bearish impulses resurface
content: The Short Sterling strip is mostly softer, and Gilts look set to return to Liffe on the back foot as well given another upturn in global equities and broader risk appetite. Although Bunds have rebounded from worst levels (to 157.84 vs 157.61 at one stage), the 10 year UK debt future is likely to gap down around ¼ point from the 121.12 previous settlement, if not more assuming the FTSE and its peers draw positive momentum from the improved tone elsewhere. Bond and STIR futures are also back in bearish mode independently as BoE members underline the more hawkish tone from last Thursday’s post-meeting guidance and QIR, while US Treasuries are also resuming their sell-off with yields probing higher. More BoE/MPC speakers due today, but CPI tomorrow will likely be the main domestic focus this week.

subject: Bunds: correcting lower on improved risk sentiment
content: The 10 year German benchmark (and its core bond counterparts) continues to take a lead from broad risk on/off fluctuations, and currently backing off again as stock markets regain a foothold after last week’s significant correction and heightened volatility. Bunds have retreated through the 158.00 level and eyeing recent lows/yield highs awaiting the EU cash bourse opens to see if the latest Wall Street rebound and recoveries in Asia-Pac equities provides a decent fillip. The Eurex low so far has been 157.66 vs last Friday’s 158.04 close and a high of 157.81 from the 157.75 initial print, with some tech support seen around 157.56 before further downside and the contract low.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Highlights include stories from BT, Melrose, Airbus and Nestle
content:
12th February 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia equity markets began a holiday-quietened week mostly positive in which the region got a mild lift as US equity futures extended on Friday’s late rebound. However, upside was contained with Japan away in observance of National Founding Day, while the ASX 200 (-0.3%) was the laggard as energy names reeled from last week’s drop in crude prices and with financials subdued as the Royal Banking Commission started its inquiry into the industry. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.7%) were positive ahead of this week’s Lunar New Year celebrations, while most of the Asia peripheries traded with cautious gains amid a lack of drivers and with various holiday closures scheduled through to next week.

PBoC skipped open market operations. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3001 (Prev. 6.3194).

FTSE

Ladbrokes (LCL LN) – Co. says full year group profit was a the top-end of guidance, revenue +4% and total group net revenue +12% ahead of last year, announces second interim dividend of GBP 0.04. (Newswires)

Tesco (TSCO LN) – Co. is planning a chain of cut-price stores to counter the growth of rivals Aldi and Lidl. (Sunday Times)

Melrose (MRO LN) – Co. accused GKN (GKN LN) of “opportunistic financial engineering” and stated that any potential plan to sell its powder metallurgy business to help to fund a bumper cash divided was flawed. GKN is expected to announce cash payout plans this week. (Newswires)

BT (BT/A LN) - Anger at BT’s failure to commit to a large-scale broadband network upgrade has triggered a new discussion of whether it should be forced to spin off its network subsidiary Openreach. (Telegraph) Elsewhere, BT is attempting to squeeze higher fees from rival Virgin Media for its sport channels against the backdrop of this weekend's multibillion-pound Premier League rights auction. (Telegraph)

Rio Tinto (RIO LN) - Co. is examining possible IPO of Pacific Aluminium business., Co. CEO also commented that there is no plans to alter the Co.’s dual-listed structure. (Newswires)

RBS (RBS LN) – Co. is in discussions to speed up fine in US related to RMBS. (Sky)

BHP (BLT LN) – Co.’s two largest shareholders have asked the Co. to respond to Elliot Management’s request for the |Co. to scrap its dual listing. (Newswires)

RyanAir (RYA LN) – CEO has warned that British investors would have to sell stock in the Co. in the event of a hard Brexit to meet EU investing rules (i.e. that a majority of investors are European. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

BP (BP/ LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT SOCGEN

THOMAS COOK GROUP (TCG LN) UPGRADED TO MARKET PERFORM FROM UNDERPERFORM AT BERNSTEIN

RELX (REL LN) DOWNGRADED TO EQUAL WEIGHT FROM OVERWEIGHT AT BARCLAYS

EVRAZ (EVR LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM NEUTRAL AT GOLDMAN SACHS

DAX

BMW (BMW GY) – The automaker will not expand its procurement cooperation with Daimler (DAI GY). (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

MUNICH RE (MUV2 GY) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM MARKET PERFORM AT BERNSTEIN

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – Due to problems with engines, co. has stopped delivering A320neo jets powered by Pratt & Whitney geared-turbofan engines and halted pre-delivery test flights. Separately Emirates finalized orders for as many as 36 additional A380 planes valued at USD 16bln. (Newswires)

Renault (RNO FP) – Senior board member Thierry Desmarest has resigned from the co. days ahead of a meeting at which the CEO is asking directors to back his chosen successor’s appointment. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

ICADE (ICAD FP) –FY net profit attributable to group EUR 170.3mln vs. prior year EUR 58.0mln. Co. to propose dividend of EUR 4.30/shr. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PAN-EUROPE

Monte Dei Paschi (BMPS IM) – The co. says its Q4 saw a net loss of EUR 502mln and 2017 saw a net loss of EUR 3.5bln. Co. Chairman sees NPL disposals completed by June. (Newswires)

Heineken (HEIA NA) – FY operating profit EUR 3.76bln vs. Exp. EUR 3.75bln. FY net profit +9.3% at EUR 2.247bln. FY diluted EPS +7% to EUR 3.94/shr. Co. expects further organic revenue and growth for 2018. (Newswires)

Galapagos (GLPG BB) – Co. is said to looking for protection against a hostile takeover. (Newswires)

Intesa Sanpaolo (ISP IM) – Co. expects a partial sale of its debt collection unit won’t take long and looks with interest at Sweden’s Intrum Justitia, although China’s CEFC is also interested according to the bank’s chairman. (Newswires)

Arcelormittal (MT NA) – Co. are looking at options to re-start their USD 4.7bln Indian unit. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

Endesa (ELE SM) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM UNDERWEIGHT AT JPMORGAN

SMI

Nestle (NESN SW) – The confectionary co. acquired a majority stake in Terrafertil, a Latin American organic food company. (Newswires)

Clariant (CLN SW) – Co. has halted plans to issue a strategy update after activist investors sold its 25% stake in the co. to Saudi Basic Industries. Additionally, CEO Kottmann told Basler Zeitung that SABIC deal beats what had been a proposed merger with Huntsman. (Newswires)

Credits Suisse (CSGN SW) – Co. faces a US class action lawsuit over USD 1bln in writedowns it took in 2015 and 2016 linked to its trading division. Co. then stated the case was “without merit”. (SonntagsZeitung)

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

BROKER MOVES

US

 

EQUITIES: SPX +1.5% at 2620, DJI +1.4% 24192, NDX +1.7% at 6413. Top sectors: IT +2.5%, Utilities +2.2%, Healthcare +1.5%. Bottom sectors: Energy -0.3%, Cons Stap +0.2%, Cons Disc +0.7%. In early trade, sour sentiment and concerns about the valuation of equities extended, lining stocks up for another grim end to the week. However, in afternoon trade, the DJIA and SPX fell to test their 200d MA, which neither could meaningfully break beneath. The result was an immediate improvement in sentiment and buyers emerged, pushing stocks up to erase losses for the day. The run-in to the close was choppy, however, and gains appeared fragile. The weekly stats, however, still look grim, with the SPX off by over 5% in the week, straddling the 2600 handle as we close out trade. However, Friday’s gains have taken at least some of the sting out of the gains, and technical analysts were encouraged by the fact that the 200d MA held its ground when tested.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asia equity markets began a holiday-quietened week mostly positive. Japan away from market
content:
• Asia equity markets began a holiday-quietened week mostly positive. Japan away from market
  • FX markets saw a quiet start to the week amid a sparse overnight calendar and light weekend newsflow
  • Looking ahead, today sees a lack of tier 1 highlights

ASIA

Asia equity markets began a holiday-quietened week mostly positive in which the region got a mild lift as US equity futures extended on Friday’s late rebound. However, upside was contained with Japan away in observance of National Founding Day, while the ASX 200 (-0.3%) was the laggard as energy names reeled from last week’s drop in crude prices and with financials subdued as the Royal Banking Commission started its inquiry into the industry. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.7%) were positive ahead of this week’s Lunar New Year celebrations, while most of the Asia peripheries traded with cautious gains amid a lack of drivers and with various holiday closures scheduled through to next week.

PBoC skipped open market operations. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3001 (Prev. 6.3194).


UK

Visa said that UK Household Spending saw its first January decline in 5 years, while reports also stated that UK retailers suffered the worst January for sales and footfall since 2013. (CityAM)

EU plans the next round of Brexit talks for 26 February. (Newswires)

UK firms face VAT border friction in the event of a hard Brexit, while there were also reports that Brussels warned that UK asset managers face a shutout post-Brexit. (FT)

UK Home Office sources admit that work on a separate registration scheme for immigrants post-Brexit had “barely begun” and “almost certainly” would not be ready in time. (Times)

UK Chancellor Hammond has been sidelined from a series of major "road to Brexit" interventions by Cabinet ministers over the next fortnight as Theresa May seeks to agree a cross-Cabinet vision for Brexit. Theresa May and Boris Johnson, David Davis and Liam Fox - the three leading Cabinet Brexiteers - will all give key note speeches on the UK's EU withdrawal stance over the next three weeks, but the Chancellor will not take part. (Telegraph)

BoE’s Haldane said that minor interest rate increases are likely to be introduced later this year, while he also stated that inflation is currently running above target and that’s one of the factors interest rates were hiked last year. (ChronicleLive)

EU

ECB’s Nowotny said that the ECB is concerned regarding US attempts to politically influence FX rates. Nowotny also added that said that EU inflation still has room to increase so the ECB is still on the careful side, although that certainly won’t last forever and that there will be a need for higher interest rates in the foreseeable future. (Newswires)

ECB’s Visco said ECB will be patient on pursuit of its inflation goal and that it has been challenging to push up inflation expectations. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed Germany at 'AAA'; Outlook Stable, affirmed Czech Republic at 'A+'; Outlook Positive, affirmed Malta at 'A+'; Outlook Stable and affirmed Finland at 'AA+'; Outlook Stable. (Newswires) Moody’s affirmed European Stability Mechanism rating at Aa1; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)
 

FX

FX markets saw a quiet start to the week amid a sparse overnight calendar and light weekend newsflow, while the absence of Japanese participants and upcoming slew of market closures also initially kept trade range-bound. Nonetheless, weakness in USD and Treasuries then emerged as the theme for the day following comments from White House Budget Director Mulvaney, who warned that interest rates could spike on a surging deficit and stated he would probably not have voted for the Trump budget deal. This saw EUR/USD and GBP/USD as the main beneficiaries which recovered some of last week’s losses, while USD/CNH briefly wobbled and tested 6.3000 to the downside after the PBoC set a firmer reference rate.

South Africa Ruling ANC party panel Is said to meet today regarding President Zuma’s exit. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mostly higher overnight with WTI crude futures nursing some of last week’s losses, in which prices fell for a 6th consecutive session and briefly fell below USD 59/bbl. However, prices have since recovered and was just of reclaiming the USD 60/bbl level to the upside. Elsewhere, gold was underpinned by USD weakness and copper also gained amid the mostly positive risk tone.

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count W/W 975 (Prev. 946). (Newswires)
US Baker Hughes Gas Rig Count W/W 184 (Prev. 181)
US Baker Hughes Oil Rig Count 791 (Prev. 765)

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korea invited South Korean President Moon for talks in Pyongyang, while President Moon stated that they should make preparations to realize the meeting. (Newswires)

US official stated that there is no differences between US, South Korea and Japan on need to isolate North Korea until it gives up its nuclear weapons program. (Newswires)


US

Yields narrowed along the curve, with Treasuries re-establishing themselves as a safe-haven amid the stock slide. At settlement, 2s10s were steeper by c.5bps, 2s30s wider by c5bps, 5s30s steeper by c.3bps. Fixed income traders were happy to look through the budget deal reached by US lawmakers, despite the assumption that it will likely see issuance increased, likely weighing on prices. Given the sharp rise seen in bond yields over the last few weeks – which many have attributed it to better inflation prospects, solid growth, and a Fed which may hike ¾ times in 2018 – attention next week will be on US CPI data to assess how widespread inflation pressures are. US T-Note futures settled 9 ticks higher at 121-05+.
 

Office of Management and Budget Director Mulvaney said the is budget is to seek USD 3.0tln deficit reduction over 10 years and that interest rates may spike as a result of the increasing deficit, while he added that he would probably not have voted for the Trump budget deal. Furthermore, there were also source reports that Trump’s budget is said to not balance in 10 years. (Newswires)

Mick Mulvaney’s spokesman denied reports that his boss is in talks to replace John Kelly as White House Chief of Staff. (Newswires)

US White House stated that 2019 budget plan will project 3% growth. (Newswires)
